title: Apollo: the private equity baron and the paedophile
text:

Welcome to the Due Diligence briefing from the Financial Times. Not a subscriber to DD? Sign up here. Drop us a line and join the conversation: Due.Diligence@ft.com 

Why Leon Black paid Jeffrey Epstein $158m

A “confirmed bachelor with eclectic tastes, who often employed attractive women”. And, “someone who was very intelligent and knowledgeable regarding . . . estate planning and taxation”. 

That's how Leon Black, founder of the private equity group Apollo and one of the most successful financiers of his generation, viewed the late paedophile Jeffrey Epstein, to whom he paid $158m over a five-year period ending in 2017, according to a report by the law firm Dechert. 

Apollo commissioned the report after The New York Times reported in October that Black had paid Epstein at least $50m.

In the hours since the report's publication on Monday — and the announcement that Black would relinquish his role as chief executive of Apollo while staying on as chairman — there's been time to start digesting some of the answers to the big question of what the payments were for. 

It's worth reading the report, which is based on documents and interviews with witnesses including Black, in full.

But here are some of its findings — and you can go deeper with this story from DD's Mark Vandevelde and Sujeet Indap.

  • Dechert has seen no evidence that Black was involved with Epstein's criminal activities, and there's no evidence that Epstein ever introduced him to any underage woman.

  • Black attributes a significant portion of his family's wealth to Epstein, saying his advice was worth “more than $1bn and as much as $2bn or more in value”. For context, Forbes magazine estimated Black was worth $7.7bn at the time of Epstein's 2019 suicide. 

  • One of Epstein's biggest contributions was a “unique” solution to rectify defects in a Grantor Retained Annuity Trust or Grat — a mechanism to transfer some assets to heirs without paying estate or gift tax. Epstein's solution was a “grand slam” according to another of Black's lawyers, and Dechert's witnesses put the tax savings from it at between $500m and $1bn.

  • As their relationship deteriorated, Epstein attempted to extract more money. In emails, he referenced “personal matters that Black had shared with Epstein in confidence”. But there's “no evidence that those matters had any relationship to any of Epstein's criminal activity or to any of Black's payments to Epstein”.

  • In a letter sent to Apollo investors in 2019, Black insisted that he had “never promoted” Epstein to his top colleagues at the company. That statement was “not false”, according to Dechert, but Black “did positively comment on the substantial value of Epstein's services”.

  • The same letter said Apollo “never did any business with Epstein at any point in time” and “does not have, and never has had, any relationship with” him. Epstein's Financial Trust Company bought 263,257 shares in Apollo during its IPO. And in the early 2000s, it invested in two entities formed by Apollo executives, though they had no relationship to Apollo.

  • “While these facts do not render any prior statements false or misleading, it is clear that the facts informing what it means to ‘do business with' or have a ‘relationship with' are perhaps more nuanced than might appear at first glance,” Dechert said. 

Will the report and Black's job move calm jittery investors? Apollo's share price, up more than 7 per cent on Tuesday, suggests the market thinks so.

One test will be what the Pennsylvania Public School Employees' Retirement System, a big US public pension fund, decides. It froze new investments with Apollo when concerns about Black's payments to Epstein began to grow in the autumn.

In October the group said it “will not consider any new investments at this time”. Asked on Tuesday whether it was now willing to think about putting its money into Apollo funds, its spokesman Steve Esack said: “I refer you to our previous comment you referenced in your email and decline further comment.” 

A star dealmaker gets a second chance at the top

The last time Andrea Orcel was offered his dream job of running his very own European bank, things didn't pan out so well. 

In fact, he's still embroiled in a legal battle with Santander, who offered to make him chief executive in 2019, only to withdraw the offer weeks later. Avid DD readers will remember the saga. 

Now Orcel, one of Europe's most high-profile dealmakers, is back on the scene after a break from the spotlight. Italian bank UniCredit has chosen Orcel to replace Jean Pierre Mustier as its chief.

UniCredit is exchanging Mustier for a banker that has been involved in some of Europe's biggest banking deals. That includes the €21bn merger between Credito Italiano and UniCredit in 1998, which gave the bank its start as the country's only influential financial institution.

Orcel's history with UniCredit may have helped put him ahead of other candidates for the job, including former Credit Suisse chief executive Tidjane Thiam, who recently took off for Spac-land. 

But not all of Orcel's dealmaking has been up to scratch. He famously advised Royal Bank of Scotland on its disastrous €72bn takeover of Dutch bank ABN Amro in 2007, a deal so bad (it led to the collapse of RBS) he apologised for it.

Orcel, whose appointment is yet to be signed off by the board, will have to bring his best dealmaking chops to UniCredit. One of the first decisions he'll have to make is whether to buy government-owned bank Monte dei Paschi di Siena. Shareholders oppose the deal but UniCredit's board is keen for growth, which leaves Orcel to tread a fine line. 

What this means for Orcel's battle with Santander is unclear. No settlement has so far been signed on the €112m lawsuit and the bank's public U-turn is likely to stay with him for a while.

Football misses a €2bn shot

The world's richest 20 football clubs are on course to miss out on €2bn in revenue due to the coronavirus pandemic, according to Deloitte's annual money league. 

But some things don't change. For the second consecutive year, Spain's FC Barcelona topped the rich list, despite being 10 points off the top spot in La Liga, Spain's top division, after a slow start to the season.

The money league ranks clubs by revenue, which fell by 12 per cent to €8.2bn in aggregate across the top 20 in the 2019-20 season, and Barca's 15 per cent decline was mildly higher than average. 

By the end of the current campaign, the top clubs will lose out on €2bn as a result of the pandemic, according to Deloitte, namely because fans are still unable to attend matches.

But as in any crisis, the income statement tells only part of the story. 

Barcelona's balance sheet is causing alarm in some sections of the Spanish media, as the club's annual report showed the club has been negotiating with lenders and bondholders for leniency to alleviate the burden of its €488m net debt.

Goldman Sachs is advising the club on spinning off digital assets and merchandising among other business lines to raise capital from investors, according to Bloomberg.

The US investment bank has an interest in Barca's long-term health, courtesy of its leading role in the $815m financing plan to upgrade its Camp Nou stadium and improve the surrounding facilities.

Dealing with the richest club in football might be tougher than revenues would suggest.

Job moves

  • Masayoshi Son is stepping down as chairman of SoftBank Corp, the Japanese conglomerate's domestic telecoms subsidiary. The unit's current CEO Ken Miyauchi will become chairman, while its chief technology officer Junichi Miyakawa will assume the role of chief executive. Read more here.

  • The US law firm Paul Hastings has poached white-collar crime partners Jonathan Pickworth and Joanna Dimmock from White & Case.

  • New Enterprise Associates, the venture capital firm, has hired Ann Bordetsky, a former who has held senior roles at Uber and Twitter, as a partner in Menlo Park, and Sheila Lirio Marcelo as a venture partner in New York.
